items.author: David Denby
items.content: It's powerfully and richly imagined: a genre-busting movie that successfully combines the utmost in romanticism with the utmost in realism.

items.author: Pete Hammond
items.content: Campanella has laced his story with twists and turns worthy of Hitchcock and the framing device of the novel (which forces the protagonist to sort out the whole thing through writing) is ingenious.

items.author: Jonathan Holland
items.content: A deeply rewarding throwback to the unself-conscious days when cinema still strove to be magical, The Secrets in their Eyes is simply mesmerizing.
A riveting Argentine thriller spiked with witty dialogue and poignant love stories.

items.author: Rene Rodriguez
items.content: Although it is structured like a thriller, and its plot dominated by Benjamin's detective work, The Secret in Their Eyes is really a cautionary tale about the consequences of a life of too much apprehension and propriety.

items.author: Lisa Schwarzbaum
items.content: The performances are tender, the script elegant, the cinematography (especially during a virtuoso chase scene in a soccer stadium) artful.

items.author: Scott Tobias
items.content: The film sprawls across two decades and 127 minutes, but there isn't a memorable image in it.

items.author: Keith Uhlich
items.content: About as deep as a kiddie pool, which isn't to say it's an unpleasant frolic.

items.author: Wesley Morris
items.content: The secret here is that the movie is rather tasteless. It has the high, slightly nauseating stink of perfume on garbage.

Campanella, who overconfidently takes his time, outfits the film with ludicrous interrogation scenes, a drunken colleague who provides comic relief and redemptive tragedy, and a climactic flood of memories that plays like a trailer.
